SELEUCIA, (anc. geogr.), ſurnamed Babylonia, becauſe ſituated on its confines, at the confluence of the Euphrates and Tigris. Ptolemy places it in Mesopotamia. It is called also Seleucia ad Tigrim, (Polybius, Strabo, Iſidorus, Characenus) ; waſhed on the south by the Euphrates, on the eaſt by the Tigris, (Theophy∙ lactus) ; generally agreed to have been built or enlarged by Seleucus Nicanor, maſter of the eaſt after Alexander ; by means of which Babylon came to be deſerted.
It is ſaid to have been originally called Coche, (Ammian, Eutropius) ; though others, as Arrian, diſtinguiſh it, as a village, from Selucia: and, according to Zoſimus, the ancient name of Selucia was Z ochasia. Now called Bagdad, E. Long. 44. 21. N. Lat. 33. 10. There were many other cities of the ſame name, all built by Seleucus Nicanor.
